subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.

messageBody:
At 20:23 +0200 2007-05-29, Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:

> > Except that Quikscript is a revision of Shavian made by
>> the deviser of Shavian.
>
>Surely the fact that the deviser intended QS not
>to be a set of alternatives within Shavian or an
>extension of it, but a *replacement* for it
>ought to have some weight?

No "surely" about it. QS is an evolution of
Shavian. We have other scripts, like Vai and
Bamum from West Africa which have clear
evolutionary paths. We are not encoding "Ndole
Vai" separately from "modern Vai" though there
are many differences in glyph particulars.

>Also people don't pick and choose among the
>Shavian or QS characters, but use either the one
>or the other system.

People using Cyrillic orthographies ALL use one
or another subset of the whole. No one uses all
Cyrillic letters.

>After all we don't unify Latin or Cyrillic with
>Greek because they grew out of it? That's
>exactly the mistake made with Greek and Coptic.

Please remember who you are talking to. I worked
for seven years to disunify Coptic from Greek
against entrenched "we were right" arguments from
the UTC. Latin derives from Old Italic, not
Greek. And those scripts have CENTURIES of
independent development, even if there was
cross-infection back from Latin when Peter the
Great started in on Grazhdanka as opposed to
Slavonic typefaces.

>The only difference is that *historically*
>Coptic was a proper superset of Greek,

This is not so. Completely not so. I am currently
working with the International Association for
Coptic Studies to design the The Mother of all
Coptic Fonts.

>but so was Cyrillic originally,

Cyrillic shares very few letterforms with Greek.
And is used by MILLIONS of people. Read's
shorthands are used by some hundreds of
enthusiasts.

>but QS never was a proper superset OR subset of Shavian.

The flaw in your argument here is that Mr Read
devised Shavian and improved it with revisions of
Shavian into QS. There is no "historical"
relationship in the way that there is between
Greek and Cyrillic and Coptic and Gothic. The
analogy is with Sequoyah, and Mòmòlu Duwalu
Bukèlè, and even with Tolkien in his revisions of
Tengwar and Cirth.

>As for identity of deviser, that is alleged to
>be the case also with Armenian and Georgian, but
>they are not unified because of that! (See
><<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Mesrob>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Mesrob>)

Funny. Not convincing.

Sorry. A case needs to be made to disunify
Shavian and QS. So far I haven't seen anything,
and reflecting about it and studying so far I
don't think it's a credible approach.

I *will* be away for the next fortnight. Sorry,
but there will not be much time for me to engage
in discussion on this topic before the middle of
June.
--
Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com
